name: How Phishing Attachment Failures Are Reported
title: How Phishing Attachment Failures Are Reported
body:
Phishing attachment opens are tracked by a small tracking image placed within the attachment. If your users are opening phishing attachments, but their Attachment Opened failures aren't being tracked, a firewall or proxy may be blocking the connection to our KnowBe4 domains. You can view our whitelisting article for information on how to whitelist our domains.

You can optionally test whether your web filter is blocking the Attachment Opened failures by extracting the URL within the attachment. To locate the URL, open the email that contains the attachment you want to find the URL for. Once you have located the attachment, use the jump links below for instructions on how to extract the URL for that attachment type. For more information about how our phishing campaign attachments are tracked, view our Phishing Campaign Attachments article.

Microsoft Office Attachments

Microsoft Office attachments use XML-based files. Follow the steps below to view the XML data and locate the URL.

  1. Download the Microsoft Office attachment.
  2. Change the file's extension to .zip by right-clicking the file and selecting change to '.zip'.

  3. Open the .zip archive, and then open the word subfolder.

  4. Open the document.xml file in a text editor.

  5. Once you have opened the document.xml file, you will see a string like the one highlighted in the text box below. This string contains the URL.

    • INCLUDEPICTURE \d "http://online-banking.kb4.io/XcmVTjaXBpZWc50X2lkPTeMxMTQ0LaNjg5jNSZjYW1wYYWXlnbl9ydW5faWQ9OTAwqODAzJmFjdGlvbj1hdHRhY2htZW50" \* MERGEFORMATINET

PDF Attachments

A phishing attachment failure is reported when the user follows the link inside a PDF attachment. You can find the URL in a PDF attachment by pasting the link address in a text editor. Follow the instructions below for detailed steps to locate the URL.

  1. Download the phishing test attachment.
  2. Open the attachment using a text editor.

  3. The URL will display, as show in the example below.

    • << /S /URI /URI (https://phishtest.knowbe4.com/xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx) >>

HTML Attachments

You can find the URL in an HTML attachment by pasting the link address in a text editor. Follow the instructions below for detailed steps to locate the URL.

  1. Hover over the HTML attachment within the email.
  2. Right-click the HTML attachment, and select Copy Link Address.
  3. Open a text editor, and then paste the link into the text editor.

  4. Once you have pasted the link, you will see a string like the one in the text box below that contains the URL.

    • <a href='http://online-banking.kb4.io/XjayZ1cmw9aHR0cHM6y5rbm93YmU0LmNvbS9wYWdlcy9jMzk1NWIxYzQ4YQ=='>Go Now</a>

images.alt:
A view of the Windows File Explorer interface displaying the internal contents of the compressed archive `document.zip`.

**UI Elements and Context:**

1.  **Ribbon Interface:** The contextual **Compressed Folder Tools** tab group is active, with the **Extract** tab selected. The **Extract all** command button is visible under the **Extract To** section.
2.  **Address Bar:** The current navigation path is displayed as `This PC > Documents > document.zip`.
3.  **Navigation Pane (Left):** Standard Quick access links are visible (Desktop, Downloads, Documents, etc.).
4.  **Content Pane (Right):** Lists the extracted top-level files and folders within the archive.
    *   Items include three **File folders**: `_rels`, `docProps`, and `word`.
    *   One **XML Document**: `[Content_Types].xml`.
5.  **Annotation:** A large orange pointer highlights the `word` file folder entry in the content pane.
images.context: Open the .zip archive, and then open the word subfolder.

images.alt:
This image displays the Windows File Explorer interface, focused on the contents of an archive file.

**Context and Navigation:**
*   The current navigation path in the address bar is: `This PC > Documents > document.zip > word`.
*   The system recognizes the compressed file context, activating the pink-highlighted **"Compressed Folder Tools"** contextual tab.
*   The main action available is under the "Extract" group, featuring the command **"Extract all."**

**File Listing Details (Contents of the `word` directory):**
The file pane displays two primary columns: "Name" and "Type." The directory contains folders and XML documents, typical of an unpacked Office Open XML structure:

| Name | Type |
| :--- | :--- |
| \_rels | File folder |
| theme | File folder |
| **document.xml** | **XML Document** |
| fontTable.xml | XML Document |
| settings.xml | XML Document |
| styles.xml | XML Document |
| stylesWithEffects.xml | XML Document |
| webSettings.xml | XML Document |

**Focus Element:**
A thick, orange arrow points directly to the file **`document.xml`**, indicating it is the element of specific instructional focus.
images.context:
o the word folder.'>


Open the document.xml file in a text editor.

images.alt:
This image displays an Open XML (DOCX) structure file, `document.xml`, viewed within a generic code editor environment featuring line numbering and syntax highlighting. The code illustrates malicious content embedded within the document's body.

**UI and Context:**
*   **Application:** A standard Windows-based code editor application featuring a menu bar (`File`, `Edit`, `Search`, etc.) and a toolbar.
*   **File:** The active tab displays the filename `document.xml`.
*   **Structure:** The top section shows standard Open XML namespace declarations referencing Microsoft Word processing schemas.

**Critical Code Elements (Lines 15-16):**
An orange directional arrow and cursor selection highlight a specific field instruction intended to be processed by Microsoft Word. This instruction is nested within a Word Run (`<w:r>`) element, following a field character type "begin" (`<w:fldChar w:fldCharType="begin"/>`).

The malicious payload is contained within the tag:
`<w:instrText xml:space="preserve">`

The field code content is:
`INCLUDEPICTURE \d "http://online-banking.kb4.io/XcmVTjaXBpZWc50X21l...[truncated long string]...lRhdHl2aHRyZHJtZW50" \* MERGEFORMATINET`

**Analysis of Payload:**
The instruction is an **`INCLUDEPICTURE`** field code, which is directed to fetch remote content from the URL: `http://online-banking.kb4.io/XcmVTjaXBpZWc50X21kPTeMxMTQ0LaNjg5jNSZjlYWlWYYWYWX1nbl9ydW5faW9QOTAwaQDazJmFjdGlvblJhHRhY2htZW50`. This highly obfuscated URL, hosted on the suspicious domain `kb4.io`, is used to retrieve an external resource, representing a potential remote code execution or data exfiltration vector when the document is rendered.

This image displays the interface of a text editor or document debugger, focused on viewing raw structural data, likely from a PDF file.

**UI Elements and Context:**

*   **Header Bar:** A dark gray toolbar occupies the top of the window.
*   **Search/Find Control:** Integrated into the toolbar is a light-gray search field labeled "Find." To the right are two navigation buttons (Previous and Next result indicators) and a button labeled "Done." A partially visible button labeled "Replace" is present on the far right.

**Document Content and Structure:**

*   **Syntax:** The text uses a monospaced font and displays structured data resembling object definitions (e.g., PDF internal structures).
*   **Object Identification:** The data is segmented into distinct objects, including `%% Original object ID: 45 0`, `46 0`, and `47 0`. Each object starts with `[ID] [Generation] obj` (e.g., `45 0 obj`).
*   **Data Payload:** Each object block contains a dictionary delimited by `<<` and `>>`.
    *   A key-value pair `/S /URI` is present, indicating a URI subtype.
    *   The primary content is defined by `/URI (https://protected-forms.com/[long encoded string])`. The URL contains the base `https://protected-forms.com/` followed by a lengthy, complex alphanumeric string, likely an encoded tracking parameter or encrypted payload.
*   **Keywords:** The object blocks are terminated by the keyword `endobj`, which is visually distinguished using red syntax highlighting.
images.context: The URL will display, as show in the example below.

images.alt: This image displays an active code editor interface viewing the contents of an HTML file named `ElectronicDepositConfirmation.html`. ### Interface and Context **Editor Environment:** The interface shows a source code editor displaying code with syntax highlighting and line numbering (26 through 53 are visible). **Status Bar:** The bottom status bar identifies the file type as a "Hyper Text Markup Language file." It reports the file statistics: "length: 1,749 | lines: 53" and the cursor position on "Ln: 49 | Col: 14." **File Tabs:** The active tab is labeled `ElectronicDepositConfirmation.html`. An inactive tab, `document.xml`, is also visible. **Code Structure:** The visible code contains a CSS block within the `
